He moves with the unhurried dignity of a man accustomed to courts, though his eyes take in everything—the soaring Gothic arches, the Castilian tapestries, the crucifix above the throne. He wears robes of indigo-dyed cotton, finely woven, and a white turban that marks him as a man of learning. His skin is very dark, his features sharp and intelligent, his bearing that of one who knows his own worth.


When you address him in Arabic, something shifts in his expression—surprise, perhaps, and then genuine pleasure.


"Wa aleikum as-salaam," Musa Keita replies, his Arabic fluid and educated, carrying the particular accent of the Saharan trade routes. He touches his hand to his heart. "Peace be upon you also, O King of the Castilians."


He straightens, meeting your eyes with the directness of an equal addressing an equal—not insolence, but the confidence of a man who represents an empire that considers itself second to none.


"Your city is... cold," he says, and there is a flicker of wry humor in his voice. "In Timbuktu, we complain when the harmattan wind brings dust from the desert. Here, water falls from the sky and turns to stone. I confess I did not believe the Portuguese when they told me of this. I thought it a traveler's tale, like the stories of men with heads in their chests."


He glances up at the vaulted ceiling, the narrow windows, the thick stone walls.

Your God—" he pauses, choosing his words carefully, "—lives in buildings of stone, with images of men and saints. Our God lives in the words of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and forbids such images."
